text: Notes from summer. Pours dark brown. Aroma and taste are toffee, roasted malts, and some vanilla.
Bottle. Color dark brown with small head. Aroma bourbon, wood, caramel. Taste sweet, bourbon, malt, caramel.

The beer is black with moderate nougat colored foam. It is a further development of the brewery Sustenance Black Beer, which was very popular in a very short time. The brewer got the idea to barrel age it 11 months in bourbon barrels and the result is a beautiful black beer that smells of oak, vanilla, bourbon and some smoke. The taste is weak bourbon with oak distinct flavor of fresh wood, a little acid and a little vanilla sweetness. Moreover schwarzbiers licorice flavor that is clear and long-lasting. It has a retracted hop bitterness that prolongs the aftertaste of licorice and vanilla in union.
Inviting bourbon nose, heavy bourbon flavor with a solid roasty base and vanilla on the back end.

Pours thick dark, unclear forest blackish brown with a light sandy colored head. Aroma brings huge sweet dark fruits, brown sugar, and smooth bourbon so complex and rich on the palate! Flavor is just as rich and complex with dark fruits, raisins, and smooth bourbon sugar on a rich but smooth balanced body!
Smell is sweet heavy bourbon, vanilla, and toffee. Taste is bourbon, malt, toffee, and caramel. In that order. Medium body, medium carbonation, and mild foam.

Pour on tap at Old Chicago, dark brownish black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big caramel, toffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits come in to a bit of bourbon, vanilla, hints of oak. Taste is a mix of toffee, oak, vanilla into big bourbon, hints of chocolate, coffee and roast, nice molasses, hints of earth, finishing sweet.

Dark brown colour, white head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, light wood. Sweet bourbon flavour, caramel, light sour notes, raisins. Quite light body, wood, raisins.(from 355mL bottle @ Mother Kellys, RBESG 2014, London. Thanks for sharing, rb crew!)
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep brown, nose is toffee, vanilla, roast malts, taste is sweet vanilla, roasty.

Bouteille achetée chez Erzbierschof - Couleur noir avec une fine mousse brune qui disparaît rapidement et qui laisse de petite trace sur le verre - Au nez des arôme de fût de bourbon (Beaucoup de vanille), chocolat, café, on sent tout de suite que ça va être doux, avec un peu de temps on sent bien le malt rôti et des note de cerise - En bouche des arôme de vanille et de chocolat, un peu boisé en provenance du fût, des notes de sauce soja et un tout petit peu de réglisse, les arôme sont riche et complexe - Corp puissant, petite amertume, carbonation légère, douce et soyeuse en bouche, l9ngue final douce sur le bourbon et le chocolat - magnifique bière, j?aurais plus penser à une porter veillie qu?à une black lager

bottle thanks to mike (I think). pours black with a reddish brown highlight. minimal head. nose when cold is all booze. Bottle. Pours opaque black with a small bubbly head that fades to a ring. I dont think Ive ever seen that. Aromas are bourbon, lots of vanilla, oak, dark roast and ash. But I guess thats what happens when you barrel age a fairly thin black lager. Its still pretty good though, surprisingly smooth. If you want a BB beer without the booziness, this is it.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a pure black color with a small beige head. A big boozy nose with dark fruit and ash. The flavor is quite hot, boozy bourbon, sour mash, toffee, some ash dry flavors. Decent.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks solid; cola with razor-thin light beige lacing. Smells solid; dark malt and bourbon with a nice vanilla presence. Tastes like it smells with a nice, smooth mouthfeel. Good beer.

12oz bottle, thanks to Mikem409. Very dark black color. Thin brown head. No lace really sticks. Medium-plus body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. More dry in the finish. Love the bourbon barrel aroma, here. Good wood, vanilla. Works well with the big roast malt flavor of the schwarzbier. Not as big or chewy as an BA imperial stout, or even a BA stout of normal strength... The schwarzbier base is good for this, especially since I wasnt looking for anything thick right now. Just looking for that good big bourbon flavor, which this delivers on. Good moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Nice very light alcohol warmth that youd get from a much bigger barrel aged beer (but with a much lighter body). Light bit of spice. Really impressive, interesting, tasty beer.

Bottle received via trade with FlandersNed. Pours clear black with a small, creamy tan head,short retention with light lacing. Aroma is bourbon, sour oak, prunes, figs, and chocolate malt. Flavor is lightly soured oak. And dark fruits with vanilla, bourbon, and dark malt with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Pours black with a small, light tan head which quickly disappears. Nose is very bourbon forward. Light spice and vanilla with dark fruit hints - cherry, plum. Bottle from trade. Pours black with light Brown head. Aroma is bourbon. Taste is lots of vanilla and bourbon. Flavor fades
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours dark brown with a decent tan head and a heavy treacle aroma. There is a full-bodied dark molasses flavor with a  lot of bourbon and an oaky finish A nice sipping beer.

Overall a nice beer but needs more body.

How: Bottle 12oz.  Not sure about the age, probably not old, dant remember if I bought it or received it as a bonus in a trade.  Possible thank-you to someone.
The look: Black body topped by a medium dark beige head with good retention of leaving lots of lacings on the glass.
In long: Nose is oaky and somewhat fruity bringing almost a red wine barrel sensation more than bourbon oak.  Taste is very toasted, a bit nutty, husky malt shells sensation, rather fruity (red and white grapes, berries of all kinds), mild bourbon notes, oak well integrated and very cohesive with all the flavor elements. A overall vinous sensation. Inexplicable alcohol bite .finish, is this really only 6.5% abv?  Plenty of oak tannins, astringent sharp finish with a fruity-vinous sourness.  Kind of a weird blend of flavors but overall quite tasty and enjoyable.  Yet another beer, all the empties lying around my living room say Im a badass rebel that will never be tamed but the Star Trek TNG marathon on my television tells another story.

text: Bottle shared with friends. Dark creamy pour, slight bubbly head and pretty lacing to go with it. Aroma has hints of bourbon and woody characters mixed with a nice malt backing. Slightly earthy taste but has a nice chocolate/malt base.
Bottle. Pours and tastes like a delicious barrel aged stout. Lots of bourbon and vanilla with a medium body.

This bottled brew from rbsg #16 poured a large sized head of foamy with a frothy top light brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a opaque dark brown colored body and a good lacing. Poured from 12oz bottle thanks to northernbrews, pours a dark brown with a thin head, the aroma has somce chocolate mixed in with some oak and bourbon notes, the flavor has a thick amount of chocolate with a finish of  bourbon and oak, really good.

12/24/12. 12oz bottle courtesy cbfobes! Deep dark brown/black pour with a soapy ring of tan head. Light cocoa and fudge in the aroma with oak, bourbon, and vanilla. Nice laid back cocoa and roast with plenty of BA and wood. Tasty!

from Erzbierschof - black beer under a long lasting dark beige foam; strong woody aroma, notes of roasted malts, licorice and black cherries; fairly astringent, a good malt body, a subtle carbonation and a strong bitterness; heavy woody notes in the finish; pretty dry with more licorice, chocolate and whisky notes

A big thank you to FlandersNed for sending this beer my way in our last trade. Split with Adam.

The beer is dark brown, nearing black. The beige head stands in at a fingers width, and leaves some decent lacing on the glass.

The aroma is quite sweet. Booze, vanilla, malt, light roast, chocolate.

Mildly roasty, perhaps the other aspects of the beer overshadow the roast somewhat.

Medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Sweet and boozy.

An interesting beer. Not my favorite bourbon barrel aged brew by any stretch, but worth a try. I enjoyed this.

Interesting beer.  Very light smokey roastyness is sadly overshadowed a bit by spirity bourbon flavor that is a bit boozy and underdeveloped.  I think this could use more time in the bottle to smooth out the flavors.  Interesting concept.

This stuff is great.  I loved the original, this is better.  Black pour with a small beige head.  Very inviting aroma full of bourbon, roasted malt, chocolate and hints of vanilla. Carbonation was light and very creamy.  I cant believe this is >7%, drinks like a big beer.  Full and creamy mouthfeel.  Easily the best Ive had from Shorts.

0.33l bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours a deep deep brown - near black - body with a small quickly fading and sidesticking light tan head. The aroma knocks your head back a bit. Lots of bourbon here alright! Its roasted with chocolate and dark caramel, but its definitely the bourbon thats the most prominent, aka. The King, here. It has a average carbonation level and a medium oily to watery texture in the mouth. The first thing noticed with this compared with the non-barreled is that this is so much more warming. Almost as if it has more alcohol or something. Nice and rounded chocolate and coffee touches, hints of something almost salty before its ended of both hoppy and sour with a lasting bourbon finish. Yeah, really nice and the flavors are extremely well blended. Please start barreling ALL schwarzbiers! By far the best one Ive ever had.  27.01.2012

Bottle from motortoddhead...thanks Todd! - Pours deep black with a thin tan head. Nose is muted coffee, booze-soaked dark bread, and a powdery cocoa note. Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty sweetish toffee aroma. Sweetish malty caramel and chocoalte flavor. Has a sweetish malty toffee finish with hints of bourbon.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep cola, moderate to thin foamy sand colored head, sparce lacing. &nbsp Soft woody nose, 

definite Bourbon. &nbsp Underlying beer is unidentifiable. &nbsp Pale sweet maltiness on the tongue, bourbon, a little 

medicinal aspects. &nbsp Not a heavy beer, in fact if its a Black Bier it certainly would explain why it doesnt have 

a lot malts. &nbsp Mild sweetness, very soft bitterness. &nbsp Certainly comes across as a Black Bier aged in Bourbon, 

but the barrel aging certainly takes the heavy hand here. &nbsp Otherwise its fairly light. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel 

are moderate, even a little thin perhaps. &nbsp Decent beer, but not as big nor maly as I would have liked. &nbsp 

Bourbon aging is fairly predominant, making the underlying beer overshadowed. &nbsp Had it a been a Porter, it would 

have been much more interesting. &nbsp Decent beer, but more so a product of its aging versus the actual beer. &nbsp 

Thanks Derek for the brew!
Almost black with a big beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and bourbon. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish with warming alcohol. 241111

dark plum brown, thin white bubbled head. Dirty chocolate and vanilla bordering on tequila, marshmallow sweetness, no lager notes in nose. Ultra thin body, oily chocolate sugar and marshmallow, very sweet. I do not like Shorts.

Bottle. Aroma is huge bourbon aroma, touch of wood, but what do you expect. Flavour is bourbon mixed with a full flavoured schwarz beer, but still the bourbon dominaties too much imho. Interesting, but id think it would be better if this brew is mixed with at least 50% of the regular.

Bottle at home. Black pour, foamy tan head. Aroma is full of bourbon, leather, vanilla and chocolate. Flavor is overly bourbon, quite harsh, while the body is quite thin. Sharp, almost a bit sour finish. Quite out of balance. Still enjoyable though.
UPDATED: OCT 27, 2011 Bottled. Ordered from www.erzbierschof.ch. Vanilla throughout. Sourish. Practically no carbonation at all. Rather dry. Interesting and quite pleasant.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2011 Bottle. Frothy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy messy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Strong chocolate notes, alas exstremly messy beer due to the bourban barrel. Average moderate bitter not pleasent finish. Oily palate.

21-OCT-2011, bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
Following the original Sustenance this is really different.
Black(!) with lasting beige head.
Bourbon nose...
Taste is bourbon...
Bourbon almost killed the underlying brew.
The roastedness is almost gone but then again I like the bourbon element.
A bit thin bodied but interesting schwarzbier.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear dark brown with an off-white head. Sweet with aromas of bourbon and lakridskonfekt. Also hints of coco-nut and alcohol. Medium to full bodied. Medium carbonation. Dry and sweet finish with aromas of roasted malts. Good.

Sampled from a 12 oz. bottle at STLHops Pinball Party. Pours a dark brown with a minimal beige head. Whoa, Nelly. This one is infected. Aroma of heavily buttered movie theatre popcorn and nothing else. Same could be said for the flavor. Medium-bodied, with soft, low carbonation and a buttery, smooth mouthfeel. This is the most accurate replication of movie theatre popcorn Ive ever had in a beer. Certainly that counts for something.

Bottle. Deep brown body. Fizzy, light tan head, quickly diminishing. Aroma of roasted malts, bourbon, oak, vanilla with hint of  licorice and alcohol. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. The bourbon compliments the beer rather than overpowering it. However, the beer is too sweet to compliment the bourbon. The roasted flavors and bourbon work together well. Tastes of molasses, bourbon, vanilla, cocoa and bourbon. An interesting beer.

Botella. Black colour, beige big head, lively, good lacing. Sweet caramel roasty malty vanilla bourbon like aroma. Ók mouthfeel, rather thin like. Sweet roasty malty spiced bourbon woody flavour. Sweet well lasting woody bourbon malty finish.

12 oz bottle from the brewery.  Pours black with a light tan head.  Aroma, holy hell, its all kinds of sweet vanilla frosting, molasses, bourbon, cocoa.  A bit more restrained in the flavor department, but still similar, sweet with molasses, bourbon, vanilla, smoke, oak, cocoa, red grape.  Again kind of frosting-esque in its sweetness.  Deep and complex beer, yet it has the refreshing palate of a lager.  Very surprising and extremely good.

Bottle 12fl.oz.[ Trade by saxo ]. Clear dark red brown colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, toasted, roasted, caramel, toffee, butter, queasy sweet. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, dark malt, berry, chocolate. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110819]
Bottle. Very dark brown with small brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, liquorice, vanilla, chocolate, sweet, bourbon, littler bitter.
Dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of dark caramel, bourbon, vanilla, oak, and a hint of spice. sweet fruity flavour with strong notes of oak, and a peppery spicy finish

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are vanilla, roast malt, bourbon, fruits and hops.
Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, Ulfborg 2011. Pours black with a small creamy head and lacings. Sweet liquorice, toffee, vanilla and cookies. Smooth and sweet. Yet - very tasty. I like it.

Draft at RBSG on the bus. Pours a deep brown-black with a soft tan head. Nose is bourbon and then toasty malts. Bourbon is dominant as this isnt very aromatic to begin with. never had the regular version, but, surprisingly, the barrel didnt seem to dominate this beer too much.   nice clean light roast, chalky cocoa.   dry.   vanilla, bourbon touch.   nice.

Bottle thanks to FlandersNed. Pours black. Light tan head. Nose/taste of milk chocolate, vanilla, bourbon barrel, cocoa, wood and black malt. Smooth creamy mouth feel. Well balanced. Body on the thin side.

Bottle, bought @ Skjold Burne, Aarhus.
Deep brown to black with a medium, fairly creamy, beige head. Aroma has heavy vanilla caramel sweetness, almost like Werthers Echte. Rye bread, oak, sweet toffee. Bottle courtesy of pellegjr.  Pours dark brown with a thin white head.  Smells of oak, vanilla, cognac, some try malt, toffee, boozy.  Tastes of chocolate, some earthy hints, spicy, oaky, dry, some bourbony hints on the finish.  Enjoyable!

Bottle, pours black with some chestnut at the very edges, creamy mocha head, aroma is marshmallow, burnt sugar, estery bourbon, sweet and creamy up front w/ an interesting dry bourbony finish that provides great balance to the big malt, a very interesting and delicious brew

Bottle. High creamy and lasting light brown head. Very very dark red brown body, close to black. Sweet vanilla wood earth bourbon aroma without the expected coffree. 





Bottle. High creamy and long lasting, good looking, light brown, creamy head. Very dark, almost black, red brown, body. Sweet caramel vanilla butter aroma. Sweet toffree coffee caramel flavor with just a hint of hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste. Wonderfully balanced flavor with just the right amount of alcohol level. Impressive taste for a beer with this alcohol level.

RBSG 2010 - On tap on the damn bus to Ypsilati! Beer was poured into a drinking device. Aromas of bourbon, biscuit, stinky coffee and chocolate, vanilla, mulled oranges, amazing cherries and oatmeal with milk. The taste is very mild coffee, slighly watery?, I think the coffee is more like of of those iced coffees, vanilla, brown sugar and light spices, cocoa, fudge, some booze without the alcohol, biscuit and mildly sweet. Slight ash tray mouth. I think I drank 4 glasses.

reviewed 6/15/2009
Received in trade from jtrockchalk in the Black Booty Bif, Thanks for the opportunity!

Pours a deep dark brown with the faintest of ruby highlights and a huge bubbly off white head that sticks around forever. Smells of lemony citrus, bourbon, vanilla, faint bit of bretty horsehair, and cocoa. Slightly sour on the nose, is that supposed to be there, or did some bugs hitch a ride from barrel to bottle? This would certainly explain the spirited carbonation. Taste is a bit sour with some chocolate, bourbon, and vanilla thrown in. Carbonation is quite high, body is medium but filled with bubbles, mouthfeel is creamy but slick. I enjoyed this one, but Im not sure its a schwartzbier anymore. Very flavorful, but the carbonation ruins the mouthfeel for me. Id love to try a fresh bottle if someone wants to send me another.

sampled at RBSG 2010 - Pours near black and smells of roast malt and bourbon.  The flavor is roasty with a light bourbon character.  Its medium bodied and while its alright, seems to be lacking something.  It doesnt come together as well as I expected nor have the bourbon character one would think 11 months would give it.

From notes:

Pours pitch black and completely opaque without even the slightest hint of lighter color when held to a light source. Quite viscous looking with a half finger mocha colored head that quickly settles into a lasting ring. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Intensely boozy aroma with a huge barrel presence. Lots of sweet boozy bourbon along with some earthy oak and faint vanilla. Underneath there is a slight smokey malt presence with hints of chocolate, toffee and roasted coffee bean but the nose of this beer is all about the bourbon.

Medium bodied and slightly viscous with a very prominent bourbon flavor. Again, as in the aroma, the barrel character dominates the flavor with a burst of hot, boozy bourbon that lingers throughout, slightly overpowering the other flavors. Slight earthy oak and faint vanilla/toasted coconut but the bourbon and hot alcohol overtake these notes pretty quickly. Underneath there is a roasted chocolate malt presence with hints of roasted coffee bean, toffee and oatmeal. Slightly smokey which provides some balance to the sweet bourbon but overall this beer is just a bit too much of a bourbon bomb for my liking.

Poured from a 22oz bottle from Manny57.  Pours nearly black with some head.  Nose has some bourbon, but much less than I expected.   Taste is bourbon and roasted malts.  This was not a very boozy offering, surprising given that it rested in bourbon barrels for almost a year.

750ml bottle from deyholla, thanks Derek! Pours a very deep brown colored body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is quite nice. Lots of semi-sweet bourbon, but not overpowering in the least bit. Brown sugar, vanilla, bread, cocoa, molasses, wood, a light roast, dark caramels, and a few dark fruits. Flavor is sweet bourbon up front with lots of vanilla-wood. Caramel, a light roast, a hint of lactose sourness, cocoa, and some bread. Finishes very dry with a bit of an increasing bourbon taste and lots of wood. Fairly bitter with a light roast before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Lighter body with a soft, creamy, moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty cool beer. Solid aroma and very flavorful. The touch of sourness brought this down for me a bit, but I like the barrel-aging on it and the roasty-cocoa bitterness was nice alongside the very dry finish.

750ml via a trade with Secret Santa. Pours with a near black body and a huge foamy tan head that leaves great lacing. Aromas of brown sugar, molasses, baked bread, vanilla, bourbon, cola, cocoa, coconut, wood, and rye. Flavors of are dry, roasty, lightly vinous and a touch sour. Cocoa, dusty, roasted. Licorice. A lot of bitterness. Thin with medium carbonation. Okay.

750ml bottle courtesy of iceicebaby on BA. thanks, sean! pours a dark brown with a thick, creamy, khaki head and sticky rings of lace. aroma is great with big notes of oak, vanilla, and bourbon layered atop buttery cinnamon rolls, dark malts, and toffee with hints of raisins, dates, and maple bars. flavor is quite tasty as well, slight let down from the aroma, with more prominent dark fruits, bitter cocoa, and smoked nuts with the sweetness of the vanilla, oak, and light maple syrup coming in late with just a hint of spiced bourbon. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a bittersweet finish. overall, a damn tasty bourbon barrel brew.

(750ml bottle thanks to thirdeye11) Ruby red highlights on a brown liquid. Smells of butter- getting more buttery as I smell more and it warms up. Taste has some fruit, cocoa, toffee. This sounds good, but isnt quite as good as I expected.

(750ml bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a dark brown body with a small tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, caramel, coconut, oak, and herbs.  Flavor of bourbon, light sourness, cocoa, oak, caramel, and roasted malt.

750ml bottle thanks to Nick3.  Pours very dark brown with a small off-white head that leaves swirls on the beer.  The aroma is pretty big - bourbon, roast, caramel, spices, and oak.  Big flavor with big-time caramel and toffee, spices, anise, roast, hazelnut, bourbon, and oak.  Solid stuff.  Medium-bodied with medium-low mouthfeel and only slight booziness.  Pretty good -bal aged beer, but not a standout.
Tap @ HopCat for RBSG10 - chocolatey, carmelized roast. pretty tasty. boozey espresso and whipped cream, earthy coffee bitterness in the finish. Toffee pecan baked goods. Nice, but not amazing.

(750ml bottle via trade with deyholla) clear dark brown pour with oily tan bubbles. Nose of bourbon, brown sugar and chocolate. Taste of bakers chocolate, mild bourbon, raisins, and toasty. Watery body, surprising for the style, nice toasty sweet bourbon finish that is somewhat creamy despite the lack of body.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, black coffee color with  creamy foam, aroma of vanilla, oaky, flavor of vanilla, butterscotch, bananas and cashew
Thanks jhenry04.  Poured dark brown, bourbon, wood, vanilla, roasted malts.
Pours deep brown with a tan head. Full smooth Bourbon and vanilla in the nose. Burnt caramel like creamed brule but not as sweet. Smooth mouthfeel.

On tap at HopCat during RBSG. Poured a black color with a large frothy brown head that was mostly lasting and produced excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted malt, bourbon, wood and vanilla aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Draft. Stopped in the brewery and had a little sampler of several beers. Very similiar to the regular version with the exception of the bourbon flavors and notes. Very distinct bourbon notes in the nose. Fairly strong bourbon flavors in the taste along with vanilla and chocolate. Very smooth. Tan head with good lace.

On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids. Deep opaque brown body, medium tight cream head. Strong, buttery oak nose, with roasted malts and cocoa. Oak barrel flavors dominate the body, with bourbon and buttery tannins in addition to alcohol heat (despite the relatively low reported ABV). Beneath the oak and bourbon lurk sweetish berries and chocolate, although the base beer is mostly overwhelmed. Hot and a bit thin, an interesting aging experiment for a rather light beer.

Keg on the bus at RBSG. Pours a deep brown with good lace and an espresso swirl head. The aroma is vanilla with some oaky bourbon notes, some maple syrup, and some coco. The flavor is very nutty with some coffee, some maple syrup, and a nice mild bitterness. The alcohol is present in the flavor but it is mellow and mixes well with the bourbon and earthy flavors of the beer.
Keg on the RBSG bus. Black with a nice lacy head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, a little chocolate. Rather light body, with a distinct sour edge. Lots of barrel flavor, little roasting.

Sampler on tap at HopCat (Grand Rapids, MI). Pours a dark brownish copper, good haze, a frothy offwhite head laces well sticks around as a thicker film. Aromas are a touch daçrkepr roast, a touch of bourbon lingers, wet oak and vanilla, a touch of licorice. Flavors are a treat with that decent bourbon kick, light booziness but it really is overshadowed by powerful oak and vanilla for a smaller beer. Better than the base, but both have their place.

On tap on RBSG bus. Imperial brown-ish. By that I mean it is like what lots of brewers would call an imperial brown. A bit less roasted than an RIS with more biscuity, toasted malts. Aroma has that black lager, milky caramel sweetness. More maple syrup than Canadian Breakfast.

On tap at the HopCat, part of RBSG festivities.  Big, black pour with light tan head.  Aroma of bourbon first, then the deep chocolate layers of the base beer.  Flavor is vanilla, bourbon, chocolate fudge, oreos.  So delicious and decadent.  Impressive how well this beer lends itself to bourbon barrel aging.  Great beer, the bourbon definitely works.  I love it.

RBSG Bus beer. Pours a hazy black-brown color with a small beige head. The aroma is mild with sweet malts nuts and whiskey. The taste is similar with sweet roasted malts, toasted earthy grains and some whiskey. Palate is full and malty with soft carbonation. Finishes dry and medium in duration. Overall: I loved this brew ended up up having three glasses.

Draft on the RBSG Friday Bus Trip. Pours cola brown, medium off white head, spotty lacing. BIG Bourbon nose, with fig, smoke, coffee, quite whiskey dominated, but still very solid nose. Flavors are soft and sweet, the bourbon character isnt so forcefully apparent. Cocoa finish. Nice.

Served on draft at Hopcat in Grand Rapids. Pours a dark brown color with a thin white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of bourbon with a big buttery note and some faint cherry notes. The taste is bourbon, cherries, a buttery note, faint nuttiness and faint hops in the finish. Medium-full bodied. Decent beer.

On tap at Hopcat.  Black body with thin white head.  Smell is all butter, like movie theater popcorn butter.  Pretty off putting.  Taste is butter, butterscotch, and bourbon.  The body is good but the whole butter thing is way too much for me.  I had to power through this one.

tap at hopcat, gr mich. black body with off white head. aroma of caramel, milk chocolate, sweet oak, and diacetyl.  flavor is similar with big oxidative notes, grass and an earthy finish to complement the sweet body.

Growler - Thanks Derek! Shared with Ratman in his comfy abode. Nice rich dark brown pour with a small head. Good lacing and mildly carbonated. On tap. Poured a very dark brow with an off-white head that lasted and laced. Aroma had plenty of sweet bourbon notes with underlying sweet and dark grains. Flavor was similar with plenty of sweet bourbon that blended well with sweet grains and a bit of chocolate.
Bottle: Poured a brown color with off white head. Aroma is thick burnt malt and nice bourbon mix. Taste is very burnt roasted malt that is cut by bourbon old age.

Big thanks to hoppymeal for hooking me up with this one.  Pours brown with an off-white head.  Nose is chocolate, roast, bourbon, earth, spice, and some fruity notes.  Flavor is similar with bourbon, dark maple, molasses and wood.  Interestingly smokey in places.

bottle shared by nbutler11 on 1/25/2010.
 
walnut-y orange-ish brown pour with a tan head which fades to last as a film. 

the nose is really fruity... dried figs stand out along with chocolate, vanilla, very smooth bourbon and its spices, grain/malt sweetness and piloncilla.

Many thanks to Steve for the 09 bomber!  Poured clear cola brown with a tightly-packed beige head.  The aroma opened with sweet bourbon and sour oak with toasted molasses and sweet vanilla not far behind.. coconut and crispy burnt marshmallow accents as it warmed up.. fleeting, soft notes of Jack & Coke right on the back of the nose. Bottle shared by BOLTZ7555.  Thanks Jason!  Deep amber red pour with a foamy tan head.  Lots of toasty sweet malt, wood, vanilla, chocolate, caramel and bourbon.  Really nice brew!

22oz. bomber, with a big thanks to rbridges01 from over on BA.  Pours dark brown with some ruby highlights and a large and lasting creamy tan head.  Aroma is milk chocolate, charred wood, vanilla, a little bourbon and smoke, and some dark fruit.  Flavor was quite nice, with more chocolate and dark fruit with gentle highlights of wood, vanilla, bourbon and light smoke.  Good stuff, thanks again Ron!

Deep dark brown bordering black with a thin latte head that left some sticky, web-like lacing inside the glass.  Light wood in the nose accompanying subtle bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, and charred malt.  Flavor is more assertive than the aroma with the before-mentioned observations being magnified significantly.  Rich, hearty, enjoyable.  Really nicely done.

Bottle shared by the always generous BOLTZ7555.  Pours deep dark brown with a thin beige head.  The nose is fruits, sour oak and booze.  The taste is vanilla, roasted malt, wood and bourbon.  Damn good beer  thanks Jason!

Sampled October 2009
A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a three finger thick, lightly browned, tanned colored head.  The beer is quite black in color that shows a brilliantly clear, rich ruby hue when held up to the light.  The aroma is definitely spiced with an ample signature of Bourbon, though it is not overwhelming; notes of toasted coconut, vanillin, spicy oak, and a touch of heat from the Bourbon.  I cant really notice much of the base beer underneath the Bourbon though; perhaps a touch of toasted malt.

The beer tastes fairly dry with a touch of tartness from the oak and Bourbon.  Notes of vanillin, some coconut and a bit of spicy Bourbon in the finish are noticeable, but dont play nearly as big a role as they did in the aroma.  There is a touch of toasted malt noticeable in the finish as well as hint of roasted malt that tastes a bit like black coffee.  A touch of Bourbon heat is brought out by the oak more so than actual alcohol.  This feels quite light bodied on the palate, but that isnt unexpected as this isnt the world strongest Bourbon aged beer; the carbonation adds a prickly texture that tends to make this beer seem a bit thin at first, but releasing the extra carbonation produces a creamy texture despite the light body.

This is a fairly one-dimensional beer with the Bourbon being quite dominant.  If you can appreciate that sort of thing then you will likely enjoy this beer as it is done pretty well here.  This does have a nice vanillin and coconut character to it, though it is a bit hot and spicy from the Bourboned alcohol at times.  I could definitely wish for more dark malt character to come through, but this more than a serviceable brew for this chilly Arizona weekenend.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear dark dark brown (almost black) cola color - white head. Bourbon, vanilla, coconut, alcohed, burned, roasted, sweet notes, light smoket, wooden. Nice.

Bottled. Dark brown head with a red gleam. Light brown head. Aroma of spice, light roast, sweetness, vanilla and fruits. Flavour of vanilla and barrel, fruits, sweetness and light herbs. Medium to full bodied. Sweetish and spiced end.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear red brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet aroma of dried fruits, liquorice, oak, vanilla and bourbon.

Dark mahogany with a medium deep beige head. Sweet aroma with plenty of bourbon, roasted malt, lacto and woody notes. Sweet flavour with hard roasted malt, caramel, plenty of bourbon and chocolate notes. Finished dry.

clear brown, smooth offwhite yellowish head.
aroma is nutty, roasted grains, licorice
flavor is licorice, wood (barrel aged notes) , roasted rains. well balanced, well tasting id say imperial stout, not schwarzbier. barrel aged notes dominate.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours a clear dark brown with a warm tint of red with and a  beige head. Fat bourbon nose. Rather light body, roasted malts, plenty of vanilla and roast, some dried fruits and loads of Bourbon. A fun beer - try serving this for a German! 280110

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is distinct bourbon and wooden, dark caramelish. Mild fruity note. Sweet vanilla malty flavoured. Light bourbon warmth from back of the tongue. Smooth malty finish.

Black is the new gold and bourbon is the new wine. Dont believe me? Find a bourbon barrel aged beer, let sit for a few months, pop, pour, smell, sup, and savor. As her warm nectar kisses your lips, you too will be a born again believer. Shorts Brewing is a little old brewpub located in Bellaire, Michigan and they have been offering up some fantastically innovative beers. While all have been tasty, some have been out-of-this-world fantastic. Their Smores Stout comes to mind, and seeing as I am gazing fondly at my glass filled with their Bourbon Barrel Soaked Sustenance Black Beer, my hopes are reasonably high.


Very deep clear brown-black with little head, a khaki necklace, and a scattering of large bubbles decorating her surface. Being a growler of fresh brew, I wasnt expecting a voluminous head; tis the nature of the game, but neither is she flat and oxidized. No need to dilly-dally as her nose reaches out with drunken authority and smacks me right upside the head before piercing my heart with bourbon soaked dark fruits: raisins, plums, figs, and dates. Licorice root meets bourbon-stewed black cherries, pits included, while wood lingers in the background with a hint of warm brown spices. Burnt molasses and caramel? Mm tasty. Licking lips already damp with anticipation, we meet in a dry, slightly burnt sweet kiss as cinnamon and nutmeg dry the front of my palate. Wheres my bourbon? Oh! There she is. Bourbon comes rushing in for a long finish rich with steeped dark fruits, burnt sugars, particularly molasses and caramel, charred wood, licorice root, and a hit of chili spice for added warmth. Toasty and tasty, my chest immediately picks up a joyous glow. My breath is peppered in chili powder, charred wood, and bourbon nectars. Overall, her body is of a pleasantly balanced medium weight, making for a dangerously easy quaffing session as my empty glass testifies.


The Shorts Bourbon Barrel Soaked Sustenance Black Beer was mighty tasty and well-balanced. The bourbon shone through with deep riches which for some may be a turnoff, but I am an unabashedly unashamed bourbon freak. The more bourbon the better, in cases such as these. I am also pleased to say though that her character as a Black Beer was not overshadowed; in fact, the two worked together in almost flawless perfection. Where one started and one stopped, I could not tell, making for a seamless marriage of palates.

22oz bottle @Pauls Gathering Thanks JoeMcPhee-pours a brown ring for a head and dark brown color.  Aroma is sour, bourbon, medium/dark malt.  Taste is bourbon, medium/dark malt, secondary earthy hops.  Somewhat hot.

Thanks to JW77 for another cool beer! Dark pour.  Aroma is loaded with some sweet bourbon notes, oak, coconut, roasted malt and a bit of chocolate. Flavor has a nice hit of bourbon right off, followed by dark malt, wood and some coconut and vanilla.

Deep black pour with a sticky off-white head.  The nose is fairly unusual.  Toasty/cocoaish malt with a bit of lightly salty toasted malt.  Fairly salty with a kiss of toasted malt and light cocoa on the back.  Meh.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with mibirder.  Pours a very deep reddish brown, not quite black, that is barely translucent when held against sunlight.  The head is creamy and bubbly lasting through the first third of the glass and leaving patchy lace.  Very pleasant aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla and oak along with a few alcohol vapors.  The flavor is less intense than the aroma and includes bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak and malt.  Lacks the rich textural mouthfeel I associate with bourbon barrel aged beers like this, which is no fault of the beer as this is not a stout.  I guess I am a victim of Pavlovian conditioning, but I do miss it.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Pours black from the bomber with a creamy tan head.  Brimming with vanilla, bourbon, roasted coffee, and red grapes.  The best beer Ive had from Shorts thus far.  Awesome. Bomber.  Pours a dark cola brown color with a small, foamy, cream colored head.  A sudsy, sheeting wash of froth rejoins the body almost entirely.  The aroma is completely out of left field....I can not believe how much it reminds me of a Jolly Pumpkin beer.  A dark cocoa malt base shows formidable notes of soured, funky oak, vanilla, moderate spices, and dry brett.  Sour mash Kentucky bourbon shows subtly on the nose.  The flavor profile is even more sour and bretty than the aroma indicates.  The funky, old, vanilla laden oak gives just the right amount of bourbon heat, while lactose serves as a bridge to the bittersweet, dark cocoa maltiness.  Substantial in both body and carbonation, the brett imparts its signature dry, parching mouthfeel, sourness intensifying on the finish.  This is a great beer.  If I had to sum it up into a single phrase, it would be - Bourbon Barrel Aged Jolly Pumpkin Madrugada Obscura.  It really is almost a dead ringer.

22 oz bottle.  Clear, but deep purple brown with a splotchy beige and tan head.  Odd nose of grapes and coffee with hints of bourbon.  Medium body with a sour tang.  Taste is equally as strange with plum, mocha and red wine.  Bourbon and coffee to finish.  Always a radical brew from Shorts.

12-oz. Thanks, BVC! Crystal clear rubied dark amber. Thin, loose tan head. Bourbon, vanilla, oak, and caramel on the nose. Creamy, medium body. Figs, vanilla, caramel, bourbon and oak on the mid-palate. Nice mild finish. This one jumped up and grabbed attention; nice stuff for sure.

Bomber from masonjer.  Thanks.  Shared with my girlfriend Cyn and friends over dinner.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nose is sweet, smoky, malty with a touch of bourbon. Taste is sweet and malty with a big malty back bone, well balanced and tasty.

22oz Bomber

Recieved this in an ongoing trade with hoppymeal, thanks again Derek! Sustenance pours black with deep chestnut highlights when backlit. A creamy two fingers worth of mocha head rose on the pour and as it slowly fell left thick sheet lacing down the glass. Each drink leaves great, thick drink lines behind. The head eventually settles to a half finger cap atop the black body. 

The first thing that hits my nose is the effects of the barrel "soaking" as the bottle implies. Damp oak, bourbon, and vanilla come forward in that order of intensity and although the barrel aging is most prominent it’s soft and allows the schwarz to come through nicely. Each swirl of the glass brings along a solid roastiness and espresso. A mouthwatering beer the second I bury my nose in the glass.

Flavor keeps in stride with the aroma. Roastiness and coffee grounds upfront lay the foundation for the barrel aging. The maltiness is present throughout the drink allowing the bourbon to be a complimenting, as opposed to dominating, characteristic. The damp oak falls back compared to the aroma. The bourbon is brought to the front, followed closely by vanilla, and last but certainly not least is the damp oakiness. The bourbon finishes things off with a nice heat and hit of booziness. This is a super high quality schwarz from Short’s.

One of the reasons I love schwarz biers is the body. This follows stride with some of the best but adds a bit of creaminess from the barrel aging. Medium body that leaves a slickness on the tongue.

For a barrel aged beer this is highly drinkable. The lighter body and a manageable abv keep this flowing without a problem. As a matter of fact I’m drinking this glass way too fast. I can’t slow down.

I thought this would be a good beer, just as all Short’s beers are, but I didn’t expect to be drinking something so good. This is a phenomenal beer. So many barrel aged beers are over the top in whatever liquid the barrel previously held but Short’s hit it on the head here. Another great beer from a brewery that’s becoming one of my favorites with every passing beer I drink.

6/7/08

22oz from GrandCruDrew - thanks! Nice reddish black body with a modest tan head, fairly minimal lacing. Initial notes in the aroma are brown sugar, slight yeast, and dark fruits. Pleasant finish but not quite up to snuff.

Pours dark brown with light tan head.  Smell is roasty and lightly smoky.  Taste is slightly chocolatey and roasty with some strange light tartness.  Fuck.  I guess it was a bit above average.  I LIKE FIRE PONIES!
22oz beer.  Great beer.  Almost a meal.  Pours black with a medium head.  Slight aroma of bourbon mixed in with sugar and other fruits.

Chocolate-cola pour with mocha foam.  Green apple, minty herbs, dark chocolate, graham cracker crusts in the aroma; hugely tangy and almost tart with the swift buttery sweetness of bourbon; too much presence really.  A touch of cuban mocha sits sweetly with a fitting, darkening character that distantly balances the almost unbearable tang of the bourbon; additionally, some dark spicing of anise and  sweet tobacco forms a semblance of malt build, but the the confronting tart sweetness of the bourbon is simply too ostentatious.

The flavor is much the same; lots of dusty sweetness and almost-sour apple-like tang; full of white fruit and sparkling effervescence that seems quite out of place in this style built on munich and caramel malts and their characters, none of which are even difficultly visible, although there is a steadfast and somewhat cloying sheen of vanilla throughout.  The fruit character of its sweetness has some vinousness to it, but its sharp-edged and brittle; not raisins, plums, and dates but pears, apples, and pineapple, consistently.  Notes of a delicate bourbon, really.  And its so immersed in that fruity, tart texture that it almost seemed like an acetaldahyde-crushed beer at first, and I still cant definitely tell that it isnt.

Light-medium palate pushes the tartness through.  Lightly effervescent.  The finish really expands the borders of the flavor quite nicely, and tends to accentuate the bitter chocolate and pistachio bits of the malts; still tart, but its interesting enough at the end to seem inviting and redeemable as a whole experience.  Still I’d really love less bourbon mucking up my perception of this thing.  Thanks Derek!

22oz bomber. Pours deep, deep mahogany with a bubbly two-finger tan head that lingers for a little while and leaves a trace of lacing.

Smell is complex and interesting with bourbon definitely showing up and burning the nose a little.  There is also tons of dark fruit with raisins and even grapes on top a very sweet malt base with brown sugar as well.

Taste is just as interesting as the nose with an initial sweetness of sugar and caramel.  Dark fruits show throughout on top of a roasted malt base before giving way to a tingling alcohol finish.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied with good carbonation and leaves a sticky sweet aftertaste tinged with booze.

This is one of the best schwarzbiers I’ve ever had and I think the bourbon barrel use is very well done.  This is my first Shorts brew and I’m looking forward to more. Highly recommended!

Thanks, once again, to Jeff for this gem.

Pours a cola-like dark brown with a 1/2 inch head that quickly recedes to the very outer edges.

Similar flavors to the smell with some odd similarities to cola. Not that this is necessarily bad, but it is interesting that it ended up this way. Definitely a fair amount of bourbon here, but the flavors work, so I don’t mind. Coffee and some more dark fruits also present themselves.

I’ve not had something quite like this before, but it works well. An interesting mix of flavors with strong bourbon characteristics that make for a truly hearty schwarzbier. I can see having this with big Thanksgiving spread.

orange/brown body with a small light brown head.the aroma is a nice mix of bourbon,vanilla,wood,and some roasted malts.flavor is much of the same with some dark fruit thrown in.well balanced and still full of that b"ba" flavor.

Bottle shared at Cbus tasting 11. Poured a dark brown black color. Aroma was vanilla malts and bourbon. Taste was a bit wild for me. A bit of everything. Vanilla, malts, chocolate, lots of bourbon, and even some sort of tartiness. A fruit, cherries, maybe?

Poured a clear deep red-brown color with an off-white head.  Bourbon aroma is moderate and balanced with some vanilla and a light roast.  Well blended.  The flavor is of roasted malt and vanilla.  Light-medium bodied.

bottle from mibirder.  This is a great example of the depth and complexity that bourbon barrel aging can add to a beer.  Bourbon really complements this brew.  Very good, very smooth, and very drinkable.

Bomber. Nearly perfect black body was topped with a khaki head. The aroma was fairly strong bourbon with the oak and some vanilla. There is also a leathery note. The little bit of cola is behind that character. The taste is like bourbon and Coke more than anything else. Once you get past that mixed drink character, you get a little bit of peanuts and chocolate. But again, bourbon and Coke dominate, something I do not recall tasting in a beer. This may please those that love the sweet Schwarzbiers, but I prefer the ones that have mroe roasted character. Huge disappointment as I normally love Shorts.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Courtesy of CharlesDarwin.  Mostly transparent, dark rootbeer brown colored pour with a finger of fizzy, light tan head.  Aromas of bourbon are clearly present, but not overpowering, bringing forth notes of caramel, rye seed, vanilla and a warming booziness.  An underlying chocolate maltiness lies beneath, but its not really distinguishable as a schwarzbier.  Medium bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel with a relatively thin, light texture.  Flavors of light chocolate and caramel malt up front on the palate with a hint of roast.  The bourbon flavors develop mid-palate, and have a distinct, rye-like character hidden in there with the oaky vanilla.  Finishes with a lager-like cleanness and quickness before shades of bourbon booziness makes its way back to linger in my breath.  Enjoyable beer overall, especially in the relatively high drinkability with bourbon complexity.  Unfortunately, the distinguishing schwartzbier qualities are hidden behind the bourbon, so the lack of bigger malt flavors is apparent and missed, keeping the flavors from meshing just right.  Thanks for the special treat, Tom!

Bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a deep brown color with some auburn highlights and a moderate beige head that faded to a ring.  Aroma consists of smoky bourbon and brown sugar glazed ham.  Sweet, lightly fruity entry leads into a moderately smoky malt profile end fairly bland.  Thin, not much body a all.  A pretty big let down.

Bottle. Deep brown in color with a little off white head.  Malty fruity vanilla and chocolatety aroma. Molasses smokey notes. Sweet chocolatety roasty flavor. Vanilla notes. Sweet tasting. Full bodied. Very drinkable. Great.

Dark brown color with a small, filmy head.  Nose seems to show some contamination with wild yeast and funk, some mild fruit character (plum and strawberry,) and a touch of whiskey.  Flavors seem to be very muted.  A light touch of the base beer, with also a light hint of the barrel.  Not much to report.  Not a lot of flavor.  Super thin mouth feel with very little texture.  I dont care for this beer.

22oz bottle.  big ups to hoppymeal for hooking me up with a bottle of this.... pours dark brown with a thin film of light brown head that congregrates mosty around the edges.... aroma of charred smoky malt as well as hints of some surfacing sour fruit as provided from the barrel again..... flavors of sweet charred malt with some underlying oaky fruitiness underneath.  carbonation was there but neither adder or took away from the beer.

A- Pours a clear dark brown / blackish hue with little to no head.

S- Smell is fairly faint, non destinct sweetness along with a small roasted malt backbone.

T- Now this is what im talking about! Roasted sweetness followed by deep candied fruit notes mixed with dark chocolate. This is all tied off with a nice roasty coffee-esque flavor. Definitely subtle yet delicious.

M- Medium viscosity with quite a bit of carbonation.

D- This is definitely an easy and balanced drinker. I was a little worried about this being heavy but it isnt at all. All in all an excellent brew!~

Shared by notalush.  Unforunately, this was another cool sounding Shorts beer that just turns out very average. Pours dark brown with a fizzy head. Aroma is light booze and light bark/earth.  Taste is a bit bland with light watery dark malts. Easy drinking and a well attenuated lager.22oz bomber, Southampton snifter.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Thanks to hailsquishface for this one - dark brown beer with a ruby tint, and a fizzy, short-lived head - the oak is more apparent than the bourbon in the aroma, and some vanilla and moderate spiciness round things out - the schwarz character is pretty much gone from the aroma - the reverse is true on the flavor - the schwarz flavors are all quite present, and the barrel character actually takes a back seat - the roasty flavor of the beer is complimented fairly well by the bourbon flavor - however, the beer is quite thin, and an ashy bitterness develops as it warms that throws things off a bit - slightly doughy finish - this gets points for being quite subdued for a bourbon-aged beer, but aside from that, its still kind of a middle of the road beer.

22oz bottle. Poured an opaque black color. Head was light brown and retained its height well. Only a bit of tattered lace was left behind. Smelled of subdued bourbon and brown sugar. There were also whiffs of vanilla and molasses. Medium to full bodied with carbonation on the lower end of the spectrum. Slightly sweet up front with a mild lingering roasty bitterness at the end. Pleasant melange of flavors including the likes of whiskey, bakers chocolate, nuts, and oak. The aromas and flavors imbued by the barrel aging were present, but not overwhelming. I could definitely taste the schwarzbier.

Thank you Derek for this 22oz bottle! Poured a dark brownish color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of wood/oak, vanilla, some bourbon, nutty, chocoalte, roast, and earthy. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, chocolate, nuts, roast, and wood. Very nice!

Thanks to hopdog for sharing this.  Pours a deep brown/black with a small bubbly off white head.  Aroma of oak, vanilla, bourbon, oranges, chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, nuts and earthy.  Flavor of vanilla, caramel, bourbon, chocolate, nuts, cocoa and roasted malt.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown and a tan had.  Aroma/flavor is bourbon, wood, scotch, sweet malt, chocolate.  Very easy to drink with little carbonation.  Great.

Poured a lightly hazy black / red color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla oak, bourbon, roasted malts, some chocolate, and brown sugar.  Taste of more roasted malts, light smoke, cocoa, dried fruits, toasted oak, vanilla, and a bit of bourbon in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 22oz Bottle. Rich creamy fresh bourbon nose, with softness, cream and brown sugar. Pours a black-brown, with tan fringe. Deep. Nice light sweetness, bits of vanilla, oak, and candied caramel. Great bourbon flavor over a salty, well-malted beer. Body is balanced, creamy and deep. Nice, 
subtle barrel use. Fruitiness. Figs and jam. Great roastiness. Delicious. The barrel and base beer meld very well together, which is surprising considering how light the base beer is compared to most barrel base beers. Its fresh and well done, all around. Excellent! Thanks Sean!

(22oz bottle, thanks kmweaver) Clear red-black body topped by medium beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, roast, some cherry, smoke, light Bourbon.  Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, roast, some cherry, Bourbon, light smoke/burnt.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Dark brown/black body with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma is buttery, coconut bourbon, chocolate and roast. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with lots of buttery bourbon, chocolate, molasses, marshmallow and toffee. Medium/full body is very soft with light carbonation. Quite good. However, ken still sucks.

22oz bottle, courtesy of hoppymeal.  Thanks, Derek!  Pours a dark, reddish-cola color; light tan head with patchy, fine-bubbled lacing.  Very nice, blended bourbon  presence in the aroma; toasty oak, milk chocolate, and caramel; generous, toasty barrel presence in the aroma; soft, chewy nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lightly carbonated; soft, toasty bourbon character showing vanilla and minimal alcohol, if any; dark chocolate, caramel, nougat, and soft, toasty vanilla; velvety mouthfeel, toasty wood and oakiness; just a carefully blended, toasty and generous beer; very drinkable.  Lengthy finish, showing cocoa, dark chocolate, and toasty oak and vanilla; barrel presence is beautifully integrated.
